story:
Meet Joe

Joe is an Army veteran and has suffered for years from chronic pain caused by his service-related injuries.

In 2013, New Hampshire passed a therapeutic cannabis law (commonly known as "medical marijuana") to help people like Joe. New Hampshire law mandated that the Department must approve the first treatment center by January 2015.

Today, Joe still cannot get a New Hampshire medical marijuana registry card.

No one can.

You can't even find an application to get one. Because the Department of Health and Human Services hasn't even made the application forms.

Why Is Medical Marijuana Stalled?

That's a good question: it shouldn't be.

While New Hampshire patients suffer, the Department of Health and Human Services is dragging its feet and making excuses. No one knows the true motivations. Is someone holding it up? Or is this just a shining example of bureaucracy? To suffering patients, the different doesn't matter.

Governor Hassan doesn't seem particularly concerned that the Department isn't obeying the law. And the New Hampshire Attorney General is advising the Department not to issue patient registry cards on a rather absurd technicality.

Alternative treatment centers aren't challenging the law either, out of fear. The number of permits for treatment centers is small, and no one wants to upset the Department.

So, who is going to hold the Department accountable?

Joe Will Do It!

Joe Lachance (R-Manchester) is also a state representative in the New Hampshire legislature. Joe is frustrated at watching this bureaucratic red tape and thinks the Department should just follow the law.

As a private citizen and a patient, Joe needs your help to nudge the Department into compliance with the Legislature's mandate. If he is successful, the process should be opened for all qualifying New Hampshire patients.

With his attorney, Joe--in his personal capacity--is filing a lawsuit in Superior Court to compel the Department to finally implement the therapeutic cannabis program. The goal is compel the Department to:

  1. Approve the the first alternative treatment centers;
  2. Accept applications from patients; and
  3. Issue registry cards to patients who qualify for the program.

What We Need

We need to raise approximately $25,000 to funds costs, legal expenses, and media exposure. No part of the funds raised go to Joe, and all funds will go towards expenses. The matter is time-sensitive, and the costs reflect a compressed schedule and potential appeals. Success is not guaranteed, but someone must try!
This project will move forward even if we do not meet the funding goal. The more funds that are raised, the more resources that the team has to get therapeutic cannabis off the ground in New Hampshire.

Challenges

Whether the Department or higher up, it seems like someone does not want medical marijuana to be implemented. We expect the Department will fight against obeying the law tooth and nail, including excuses and legal technicalities. We need your help to face them head on.

Even If You Can't Support This Project

You can still help!

  • Use the Indiegogo share tools to tell people about this campaign!
  • If you reside in New Hampshire, you can contact your state representatives and state senator and ask why the Department of Health and Human Services isn't following the law.

story:
Hello, My name is Indigo, I am 10 & i live in East Devon, in England.

I have a mum a dad, 2 brothers, 1 Sister, A beagle, a cat & 3 chickens.
Ever since i was tiny i loved to cook, when i was  2 i knew how to make gingerbread men off by heart! 
every birthday all i ask for is more cooking equipment & ingredients or chickens, i do love my chickens.
Cooking makes me very happy & i realised that i'm  very good at it. I also realised that when i moved to a bigger school in a town with over 400 pupils that, lots of the children didn't know how to cook anything & nor did their parents. They didn't even know where their food came from. When i would tell my friends about eating Organic food & well bred free range  meat, they thought i was being silly.  They are more interested in dancing & gymnastics. 
I asked my mum if i could start a facebook page & then whenever i cook put up videos of me cooking it so i could show my friends & their mums & dads how to cook yummy food, however my mums phone takes rubbish videos & our computer is very old & wont upload them on to you tube. so we have been taking photos instead. I still really want to do the videos tho. i have got lots i want to share with people from a childs point of view as to why it is important that we choose our food carefully &  we cook yummy food from scratch.
My campaign is really important to me as my generation are the future & we really really need to grow up learning about sustainability & responsibly sourcing our foods, we need to see that even in the tiniest of spaces we can grow, salad leaves that we can pick every day, that even in a old black bin we can grow delicious potatoes & that there are many options to have sweet treats without all of the sugar all of the time. we need to learn that the welfare of the chickens we eat & their eggs is important & that by changing shopping habits more & more free range  chickens can be an option rather than the caged ones. 
It is our responsibility to make sure there is a future that is not all chemically grown & cruel, we the children are the future voices & we need to shout loud & proud!
if you contribute you will help me do this by buying a video camera, a camera, a good computer, & some vitally important kitchen equipment, that we don't have because it's broken, or we just don't have it . The total cost of this is £2534.
With these tools i want to make cooking videos, educational videos  & a book of my journey, I want to share these with the world. I want to speak with the education minister & try & persuade them to get food & nutrition in to schools.
What i would really really like to do as well is to try & get some form of food education in to all schools from the very beginning from teaching how to grow veggies in small spaces to basic raw food & cooked food cookery.
I want to demonstrate to people that there is healthy food that feeds the body & its totally yummy, and extremely easy to cook.
I love to make people happy & i think that my videos can do that. i can write more songs to go with my cookery videos.

DO find my facebook page  & twitter  follow my links here 
https://www.facebook.com/pages/Indigos-Kitchen/775361712501324?fref=ts

https://twitter.com/IndigosKitchen

Please please please help me achieve my dreams.
Many thanks for taking the time to read this.
Remember even if you can't help financially maybe you could Help me by sharing my Indiegogo or even my facebook & twitter.
Have a really wonderful day & please please eat well.x

Remember even if you can't help financially maybe you could Help me by sharing my Indiegogo or even my facebook & twitter.
Have a really wonderful day & please please eat well.x

story:
In 2003, I was diagnose of schizophrenia and was off and on in taking my medications. In 2005, I tried to end my life by jumping off a water tower. I am now a paraplegic in a wheelchair. My life was in shambles due to the life I lived that was all governed around drugs. I spent years of depression and went to hell and back. I finally came to end of my self and gave God a chance. Since that day, my life started to change.

On 11/07/2011 I rededicated my life to the Lord Jesus Christ. Since then I have had a great breakthrough in my health. My success has started with Jesus, then medication, being set free from every drug except sugar, those pesky doughnuts, working out, volunteering, a part time job, and all the prayers people have prayed for me. This journey has been amazing but also I have endured much suffering. These three things will help me make my life that much easier for me.

I am raising this money for these three parts for my health.

1. I need a standing A Frame. This is a exercise machine that allows a person to transfer over to a seat and with a bar pushes themselves up on to his two feet in a standing position. It is for flexibility and strength. I need this because my legs can not go straight any longer because I did not take care of them in the past and now I need this machine to help me. Otherwise I will need a surgery to cut the tendons.

2. I really need a new lower denture implant that will attach itself to my bottom gum so it will fit better. Mine always fall out and is embarrassing when eating so I just do not use the bottoms at all.

3. I can use a hand cycle bike machine in my house. This will help me to keep my weight down due to being in a chair and having diabetes and will stretch my legs because they are tied down to pedals as I turn the machine with my hands up on top. When I add weight it makes it really hard for me to roll around on my wheelchair or transfer to certain cars and trucks. I am about 50 pounds over weight.

My fund represents the price of new everything. However, if I do not receive the full amount then I will try to get what I can by used items. I really believe that I will receive the full amount. I have started off slow but ready to be more active on getting people to come to this site.

Thank you for all your help either by donating or just sending this story to people who can help. I will be totally grateful for all your help and your prayers.  Jesus Loves You and is always knocking at the door of your heart. Will you answer it or not? That is the real question.

If donations go over what is needed then I will pay it forward. I volunteer and work for a non profit organization called A.B.I.L.(Arizona Bridge to Independent Living.) That would be awesome to do if possible.

story:
Investor Summary

What Jus-T is

A versatile range of 100% natural all fruit teas using traditional recipes and methods, that can be served hot or cold and mixed with milk or water.

Where Jus-T is from

The fruit is sourced in Bosnia, Croatia, Hungary and Serbia with production facilities in Croatia and Serbia.

Where Jus-T is going

Jus-T is an exclusive premium, luxury product. Balkans, Europe, UK and Russia - can be offered to many vertical markets retail (FMCG), catering & hospitality, and others

Costs and Margins

Located in Croatia and Serbia the cost of manufacture is low.  Skilled labour and output is of high quality with deep traditions in agriculture.  Gross margins 50% with net 20%.

Volumes and Sales

Initial phase direct sales to café's, bars, restaurants - bulk pack 1 & 5 litre, with portion control dispense pump.  Sept 2015 target launch of "shake 'n' go" range to Balkans market.  Anticipated stock holding 1m units.  Jan 2016 Food and Bev expo, Istanbul for global launch.  Supply to Russian market directly from Serbia (no sanctions), an opportunity to sell quality product that would normally be barred, and to a market that imports >95% of it's annual tea needs, as well as the the thirds largest global annual tea consumption. 

Extras

Being located in Vukovar, Croatia we are able to take advantage of grant funding which will equate to approx 40% of our investments over the next 3-5 years.  This region is heavily subsidised by central and local government.


Jus - T (tm) (Jus..tea)

For Croatian Version Please click here 

For Russian Version Please click here

Jus-T is a range of 100% all natural fruit teas, that can be served hot or cold, and with water or milk! - This is a truly revolutionary approach to how we will consume and interact with tea from a grass roots level.  The founders of the business are a mixture of local and international personalities who have a wealth of experience from food and beverage industry, as well as international trade.

The founders are committed to investing in people, and have created an opportunity for the community to invest in itself, to produce, contribute and ultimately manufacture a world class product, from the ruins of devastation.

  

By involving local established skills and knowledge we are able to secure and guarantee the supply as well as quality of all the raw ingredients required for our products we shall produce from the surrounding areas of Croatia, Serbia, Bosnia and Hungary.  We have proper working agreements with local societies and organisations that have the task of promoting the local communities interests in growth, prosperity and development.  We shall also engage directly with small farmers who have capacity to supply high quality raw materials for our processes.

The nature in this region is always referred to as “God’s Garden”, simply because of the quality of the soil, the topography and its historic ability to produce the highest quality wines, sugar, honey, fruit and many other delights.  Wines from the region have been used at events such as HM Queen Elizabeth II carnation in 1953 (Ilocki Winery) and are regularly receiving Gold and Silver medals at World class wine events.

Our interest is to allow the natural heart and spirit that has been lost since 1992 to grow and beat again, ensuring that the locals are truly the benefactors of their hard work and passion, they can contribute to delivering a world class product from the fields of Slavonija.  They will feel proud in their achievements, and this will create a natural local environment that can be used as a spring board effect, to promoting confidence, happiness and healing. 

We are creating a new industry, utilising the existing local skill-sets, the knowledge, and passion; in doing so, we are developing the spirit of the community.  We shall create a revolution in the tea industry, that can come from the Heart of Vukovar.

Where are we today, and what we would like to achieve in 2015!

The recipes of our first two teas’ are finialised, taste and market testing completed, ready for commercialisation and will be available for sale locally in March 2015.  Ongoing development with bottle designers and manufacturers to complete our production tooling by end of Summer 2015.  Ongoing  tests with a dis-solvable packaging solution, we are in discussions with several interested partners who produce these types of films, and testing is ongoing.  Initial results are very positive, we are now performing shelf life and other testing to ensure quality and durability.

The brand is in the process of being protected in EU and other sensitive markets, our initial research does not indicate trademark registration will be an issue, in name or design mark, our creative energy is now on evolving the logo and labelling for the new products we have agreed to launch to the larger market in September 2015.

The two flavours we shall launch first are Cherry and Fruits of the Forest; in development are Apple and Cinnamon, Strawberry as well as Lemon and Lime. In addition to the fruit teas, we have developed natural jams and a locally known product called Ajvar (which is specific to markets in Balkans), the principal is to introduce additional recipes and products that utilise the same process and equipment, and can generate an income.  The local work force is willing and able to deliver large quantities of the best ingredients to us, and for us to prepare and cook them in a way that dates back many centuries.

Cherry Tea Portion

Our initial funding requires us to invest in technology and equipment, the initial phase of commercialisation dictates that we should purchase new machinery, which will enable us to process, cook and pack the products in appropriate containers.  We shall also invest in a small tea shop to offer and sell our products, this we have managed to secure for a nominal fee, and will be a multifunctional premises, and is currently used as a furniture shop.  It is in a high foot traffic area, located adjacent to local government administrations, local university/college and hospital.

We shall also implement the next phases of our launch to market with various parallel projects, which include “on the go” drinks (we are working with industry experts to develop a new twist and go drink bottle), dosing pumps for use in hospitality industry (bulk containers of 5-25l) where operators have solution for reduced waste and portion control. 

Our additional phases include the development of a dis-solvable tea bag (we have sourced suitable packaging, now we are completing testing and analysis) and the addition of more products that can be produced locally.

It is important that we utilise the investment capital wisely, and as an additional route to sourcing EU and regional Government assistance; this is an ongoing process, and we have retained a local expert to guide the business and its interaction with the necessary funding pools.  We believe we can achieve additional grant funding of at least 40% of our investors capital from the various sources.


It is also important for us to have cross border cooperation with Serbian, Bosnian and Hungarian partners, distribution and cooperation agreements are already in process and shall be concluded over the coming months.  This shall lead to supply of fruit and vegetables, as well as packaging agreements for markets such as Russia (products made in Serbia are easily exported to Russia and not subject to sanctions, but do have a lower rate of import taxes etc, which is of benefit to all).

As you can appreciate we are presenting this in a very public arena, there is information that will remain commercially secret.  The tea is currently produced on our behalf by a local cooperative, it is our intention to bring this process under our full control as soon as our premise has the necessary permit and equipment.

The vision is very clear and direct, we shall present an exclusive range of high quality premium products to a well established market, with our price being competitive and the quality much higher we can be sure with correct marketing strategies and partnerships we can ensure this world class product is delivered globally.

Once our brands are established, and we are satisfied with our ability to meet supply, we look to launch additional products at major Food and Beverage expos in early 2016, beginning in Istanbul.

story:
Short Summary

As some of you might already know, I am incredibly passionate about public health, and in particular how it pertains to women. Last year, I was made aware of a global health problem that women face daily: 

Every day 2,300 people die from lack of inadequate drinking water, sanitation, and hand hygiene and women lose 152 million hours collecting water for their families. But it doesn't have to be that way.

Mama Maji's mission focuses on community, empowerment of women, and giving all these women the tools they need to be catalysts in their community.

Last year through our Catalyst Walk, Rotaract raised $10,000 to bring water to the Kamrongo community. That money went to training 28 Community Health Volunteers to be advocates in their community for clean water, and then building a kiosk that will be opening soon to serve 2,500 people. 

Rotaract is hosting the Catalyst Walk again this year, and it will benefit the Homa Bay community for the same process -- training the community, building the kiosk, and fresh water for the area.

 

The Goal

I am raising money to support a 14-day trip to Kamrongo and Homa Bay, Kenya in December. I will be visiting a project in Kamrongo that I have been an integral part in through Rotaract over the past year and I will be facilitating the beginning of a similar project in a neighboring area.

 

The Cost - $1500 

This covers:

  • Immunizations needed for international travel
  • Flights to and from Kenya
  • Transportation to the training site
  • Supplies for the women needed during training
  • Two meals each day as well as clean water 

I would like to use some of these funds to sponsor not only myself, but the women we are supporting. The workshops that Mama Maji provides cover small group management skills, public speaking skills, how to design and implement a community training, grassroots outreach and how to create community work plans. 

Together we can help bring change to a community through the empowerment of women!

 

The Impact

This opportunity to travel to Kenya is important to me for two reasons: 

  1. It is an opportunity to make a positive impact in a community 
  2. It pertains to my future interests in the field of public health.

I have been studying Kiswahili in preparation to traveling to Kenya because I believe that communication is a key to building community! If we really want to make an impact, we must be able to cross cultural divides and connect. I hope to pursue a Masters degree in Tropical Diseases, an issue primarily felt in Africa. My current research is on how to prevent disease with sustainable solutions. Mama Maji not only empowers women, but helps to provide clean water to these communities: a basic prevention measure that will save countless lives for years to come. 

I believe this project is the first stepping stone to my continued involvement in African communities. 

 

Other Ways You Can Help

Help spread the word on Facebook or through email! 100% of the funds you donate will be used for the Homa Bay project.

So please DONATE if you can or HELP US get the word out!

story:
The World Health Organization, in its news release in 25 March 2014 on its website at http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2014/air-pollution/en/, reported that in 2012, around 7 million people died from air pollution exposure related causes, making air pollution the biggest environmental health risk.  Just how big of a risk is air pollution these days?

 

Over the last few years, some of the people we know died from lung cancer – and they’re non-smokers.  Nobody in his or her house even smoked.  But one thing is clear: they were constantly exposed to air pollution when they commuted to and from work everyday.  One of them also happened to work in a really old building, which increased her risks for indoor air pollution. 

How can you manage air pollution and minimize your air pollution-related health risks?  There are many ways.  One of them is a very simple: move out of the city.

When you live in the city, breathing polluted air is unavoidable.  Merely stepping outside exposes you to smoke emitted by vehicles on the road, second-hand smoke from other people’s cigarettes, and dust, among others.

Out in the countryside – where farm tractors outnumber cars, in the woods where trees outnumber buildings or houses, or at the beach where any semblance of air pollution is either drowned out by fresh air from the sea or pollution is swept away to the open water – quality air is abundant.

But moving out of the city – especially if you and your family’s already well established in your city – can be very impractical and life-disrupting.  You may have to do so many things and basically start your lives all over again.  And for most people, that’s too high a price to pay for fresh, clean air – at least while they’re still not sick from air pollution.  For you and your family, that may be the case too. 

Another option is to stay indoors most of the time.  That’s sounds like a very simple and great idea but it’s not necessarily so because air pollution isn’t just present outdoors – it’s also present indoors.  Some of the most common indoor air pollutants include carbon monoxide, radon, nitrogen dioxide, second-hand smoke, lead particles from old house paint, asbestos, and molds.  The effects of these indoor air pollutants on your body may range from as simple as allergies to more serious health problems, especially if you have pre-existing breathing-related health conditions such as asthma.

 

The most common option taken by people who are aware of the need to manage the quality of the air they breathe is using ordinary and affordable breathing masks.  These masks are usually made from cloth or other composite materials.  But ordinary breathing masks aren’t enough to ensure that you breathe in enough fresh clean air.  Why?

First, the materials from which these ordinary breathing masks are made aren’t fine enough to screen out enough of the smallest particles or pollutants floating in the air.  The best among these ordinary breathing masks can only filter up to 67% of air pollutants from the air you breathe.

Another reason why ordinary breathing masks aren’t enough to give fresh clean air is quantity.  Such masks either filter up to 67% of air pollutants or provide enough air. You see, the higher the filtering ability of ordinary breathing masks, the less air you can breathe in.  If you want to breathe in more air, the ability to filter pollutants becomes less.

Lastly, ordinary breathing masks aren’t enough because they can contaminate the air you breathe with recycled air – the carbon dioxide you breathe out.  Ordinary breathing masks – particularly those at the top of the air filtering chain – are very limited in terms of letting you release the carbon dioxide you breathe out, which allows it to contaminate the already limited fresh air you’re able to breathe in.  That is why most people who use such masks tend to remove them frequently just to be able to really “breathe”.

If moving out of the city is out of the question and staying indoors and wearing ordinary breathing masks just don’t cut it, is there anything else you can do to minimize your air pollution-related health risks?  The good news is yes, there is – with Breathe Clean!

 

 

The Breathe Clean urban breathing mask comes in 2 models: 

The Breathe Clean SOLO and the Breathe Clean PLUS.

Breathe Clean SOLO is a stand alone model, which comes in 5 available colors: black, white, blue, pink, and green.

Check out Breathe Clean Solo's key features in this short video:

Breathe-Clean SOLO is ideal for people who want to use the breathing mask for brisk walking, running, biking, or other activities where freedom or ease of movement is preferred.

The SOLO's motorized fan can operate for up to 6 straight hours on a full, single charge. 

The unit can be charged via your computer's USB port via a mini USB charging cable that comes with the unit.

Check out Breathe Clean Plus' key features in this short video:

The Breathe Clean PLUS can give you more air compared to the SOLO for up to 8 hours on a full charge.  It features a separate, rechargeable motorized air filtration unit that uses an air tube to deliver fresh, clean air to the breathing mask.

Breathe Clean Plus' breathing masks come in 2 sizes - adult and child.  They also come in 2 colors - blue and gray.

The filtration unit can be charged through an electrical outlet or your computer’s USB port using a multi-socket charging cable that comes together with the unit.

The Breathe Clean PLUS unit can also function as a portable air purifier for small, enclosed spaces such as your car or a small room.  Because it features a significantly more powerful motorized fan and a larger filtration unit, you can filter and disperse enough fresh, clean air that you can share with others in small, enclosed spaces.  All you have to do is detach the air tube from the filtration unit, turn it on, and leave it be.  It’s that easy!

If you don’t have a bag where you can put the unit in, no problem.  You don’t have to hold it all the time because you can just hook it to one of your pants’ belt loops for a hands-free experience.

Included with the air filtration unit is a USB charging cable, an electrical outlet charging adaptor, a breathing mask, an air tube, and a user's manual.

Breathe Clean PLUS comes in 5 available colors:  White, Black, Green, Orange, and Pink.

 

 

Breathe Clean is not your ordinary urban breathing mask.  It has an internal vacuum micro motor fan that filters the external air  and converts them to a more clean and fresh air:

First, Breathe Clean breathing masks feature a 3-process air-filtration system that can filter up to 99.99% of pollutants in the air you breathe.  That ensures you breathe in fresh, clean air only.

 

Process #1:     Involves screening off bacteria from the air using an anti-bacterial filter.

Process #2:    Involves screening off dangerous pollutants like formaldehyde, benzene, sulfides, and smoke using an active carbon filter.

Process #3:   Involves screening off the smallest, remaining air pollutants using an Electrostatic HEPA filter. 

Together, these 3 processes allow Breathe Clean breathing masks to give you fresh, clean air on demand.

The second way Breathe Clean breathing masks help you enjoy the same fresh, clean air that’s available in nature is through an anion layer that’s found in each of the 3 air filters. They naturally give off the optimal amounts of negative ions in the air you breathe whenever you use Breathe Clean breathing masks.

If you ever wondered why you feel good and clear-minded when you’re in the beach, in the woods, or when it’s raining hard, it’s because of the abundant amounts of negative ions in the air.  Breathe Clean helps you enjoy invigoratingly healthy air on demand.

  

The Final way Breathe Clean masks helps you enjoy fresh, clean air is via an excellent air circulation system with 2 key features:  a motorized fan and pressure-reducing valves that release circulated air & heat from the mask. 

 

Breathe Clean breathing masks ensure you get enough fresh, clean air using a rechargeable motorized fan, which draws in enough air for filtering.  The fan ensures that you will be able to breathe generous amounts of fresh, clean air anytime and anywhere.

  

Breathe Clean breathing masks help keep the fresh, clean air you breathe inside the masks stay that way by allowing you to efficiently release the carbon dioxide you breathe out – and keep it out. 

 

Fresh, clean air in – stuffy, recycled air out.  Working together, the motorized fan and a pressure-reducing exhaust valves help provide you the fresh, clean air you need for hours on end.  You don’t have to take off your mask and expose yourself to air pollution just to release recycled air, as you’ll need to do when using ordinary breathing masks.

 

With Breathe Clean breathing masks, you can enjoy fresh clean air, anytime and anywhere just like them!  Watch this video to hear what they have to say about getting fresh, clean air from Breathe Clean breathing masks.

     
 
  
  

    

 

 

Protective breathing masks will never be the same again.  With Breathe Clean, you can enjoy cleaner and fresher air while you're wearing the mask, which is already in the production stage.  With your support, we can bring Breathe Clean to as many people as possible and as soon as possible.  So pickup any or our perks today to enjoy fresh, clean air on demand.

 

With Breathe Clean you can help save yourself and your loved ones from breathing harmful air pollutants.

 

 

 

Q:  Whats in the Box?  

        Breathe Clean SOLO:     

        Breathe Clean PLUS:

     

Q:  Is there a warranty for the Breathe Clean breathing masks?

        Every Breathe Clean Product comes with a 12-month warranty against factory defect.

Q:  In case I receive a defective breathing mask, how can I replace it or have it refunded. 

      For inherent factory defect, product(s) can be replaced within a 12-month warranty period.           For refund, a 7-day refund policy is applicable.  You can email us within 7 days after                           receipt of product for refund instructions and processing.

 

Q:  How long can the filters last and can they be replaced?

     On average, the filters of Breathe Clean breathing masks can last up to 6 months before they       have to be replaced.  For the Breathe Clean Solo, you'll know if you already need to replace             the filters if you find it harder to breathe using the mask compared to when you first used it.         

     For the Breathe Clean Plus, you'll have to replace the filter cartridges when the red light                   starts to flash, even when the unit's fully charged, or when you hear its alarm sound off.  

 

Q:  Is it hard to replace the air filters and how can I do that?

      No, it isn't - you can do it on your own!  Watch these videos on how to replace the filters to             see for yourself.

      For Breathe Clean SOLO:  

     

     For Breathe Clean PLUS: 

 

Q:  Where can I buy extra air filters for the Breathe Clean breathing masks? Can I get extra air filters when I pledge to support Breathe Clean’s campaign?

      Extra filters can be brought from this campaign or thru our Facebook page store: Breathe Clean

 

Q:  How often should I charge the breathing masks?

      To help optimize the masks’ battery life, it’s best to recharge the units after 2 days of                       inactivity or non-use.  If you regularly use the masks, a blinking light will indicate that the                  masks need to be recharged soon.  For the Solo, it’ll be a blue blinking light and for the Plus,          it’ll be a green one.

 

Q:  How long does it take to fully charge the Breathe Clean Solo and the Breathe Clean Plus and for how long can I use them?

      The Breathe Clean Solo takes about 2 to 3 hours to completely charge and can operate for up       to 6 hours straight. The Breathe Clean Plus takes 2 to 3 hours to fully charge via your wall’s           electric socket and longer if you plug it to your computer’s USB port.  It can operate for up to 8 hours straight on a full, single charge.
story_txt:
The World Health Organization, in its news release in 25 March 2014 on its website at http://www.who.int/mediacentre/news/releases/2014/air-pollution/en/, reported that in 2012, around 7 million people died from air pollution exposure related causes, making air pollution the biggest environmental health risk.  Just how big of a risk is air pollution these days? Over the last few years, some of the people we know died from lung cancer – and they’re non-smokers.  Nobody in his or her house even smoked.  But one thing is clear: they were constantly exposed to air pollution when they commuted to and from work everyday.  One of them also happened to work in a really old building, which increased her risks for indoor air pollution. How can you manage air pollution and minimize your air pollution-related health risks?  There are many ways.  One of them is a very simple: move out of the city.When you live in the city, breathing polluted air is unavoidable.  Merely stepping outside exposes you to smoke emitted by vehicles on the road, second-hand smoke from other people’s cigarettes, and dust, among others.Out in the countryside – where farm tractors outnumber cars, in the woods where trees outnumber buildings or houses, or at the beach where any semblance of air pollution is either drowned out by fresh air from the sea or pollution is swept away to the open water – quality air is abundant.But moving out of the city – especially if you and your family’s already well established in your city – can be very impractical and life-disrupting.  You may have to do so many things and basically start your lives all over again.  And for most people, that’s too high a price to pay for fresh, clean air – at least while they’re still not sick from air pollution.  For you and your family, that may be the case too. Another option is to stay indoors most of the time.  That’s sounds like a very simple and great idea but it’s not necessarily so because air pollution isn’t just present outdoors – it’s also present indoors.  Some of the most common indoor air pollutants include carbon monoxide, radon, nitrogen dioxide, second-hand smoke, lead particles from old house paint, asbestos, and molds.  The effects of these indoor air pollutants on your body may range from as simple as allergies to more serious health problems, especially if you have pre-existing breathing-related health conditions such as asthma. The most common option taken by people who are aware of the need to manage the quality of the air they breathe is using ordinary and affordable breathing masks.  These masks are usually made from cloth or other composite materials.  But ordinary breathing masks aren’t enough to ensure that you breathe in enough fresh clean air.  Why?First, the materials from which these ordinary breathing masks are made aren’t fine enough to screen out enough of the smallest particles or pollutants floating in the air.  The best among these ordinary breathing masks can only filter up to 67% of air pollutants from the air you breathe.Another reason why ordinary breathing masks aren’t enough to give fresh clean air is quantity.  Such masks either filter up to 67% of air pollutants or provide enough air. You see, the higher the filtering ability of ordinary breathing masks, the less air you can breathe in.  If you want to breathe in more air, the ability to filter pollutants becomes less.Lastly, ordinary breathing masks aren’t enough because they can contaminate the air you breathe with recycled air – the carbon dioxide you breathe out.  Ordinary breathing masks – particularly those at the top of the air filtering chain – are very limited in terms of letting you release the carbon dioxide you breathe out, which allows it to contaminate the already limited fresh air you’re able to breathe in.  That is why most people who use such masks tend to remove them frequently just to be able to really “breathe”.If moving out of the city is out of the question and staying indoors and wearing ordinary breathing masks just don’t cut it, is there anything else you can do to minimize your air pollution-related health risks?  The good news is yes, there is – with Breathe Clean!  


The Breathe Clean urban breathing mask comes in 2 models: The Breathe Clean SOLO and the Breathe Clean PLUS.Breathe Clean SOLO is a stand alone model, which comes in 5 available colors: black, white, blue, pink, and green.Check out Breathe Clean Solo's key features in this short video:Breathe-Clean SOLO is ideal for people who want to use the breathing mask for brisk walking, running, biking, or other activities where freedom or ease of movement is preferred.The SOLO's motorized fan can operate for up to 6 straight hours on a full, single charge. The unit can be charged via your computer's USB port via a mini USB charging cable that comes with the unit.Check out Breathe Clean Plus' key features in this short video:The Breathe Clean PLUS can give you more air compared to the SOLO for up to 8 hours on a full charge.  It features a separate, rechargeable motorized air filtration unit that uses an air tube to deliver fresh, clean air to the breathing mask.Breathe Clean Plus' breathing masks come in 2 sizes - adult and child.  They also come in 2 colors - blue and gray.The filtration unit can be charged through an electrical outlet or your computer’s USB port using a multi-socket charging cable that comes together with the unit.The Breathe Clean PLUS unit can also function as a portable air purifier for small, enclosed spaces such as your car or a small room.  Because it features a significantly more powerful motorized fan and a larger filtration unit, you can filter and disperse enough fresh, clean air that you can share with others in small, enclosed spaces.  All you have to do is detach the air tube from the filtration unit, turn it on, and leave it be.  It’s that easy!If you don’t have a bag where you can put the unit in, no problem.  You don’t have to hold it all the time because you can just hook it to one of your pants’ belt loops for a hands-free experience.Included with the air filtration unit is a USB charging cable, an electrical outlet charging adaptor, a breathing mask, an air tube, and a user's manual.Breathe Clean PLUS comes in 5 available colors:  White, Black, Green, Orange, and Pink.  Breathe Clean is not your ordinary urban breathing mask.  It has an internal vacuum micro motor fan that filters the external air  and converts them to a more clean and fresh air:First, Breathe Clean breathing masks feature a 3-process air-filtration system that can filter up to 99.99% of pollutants in the air you breathe.  That ensures you breathe in fresh, clean air only. Process #1:     Involves screening off bacteria from the air using an anti-bacterial filter.Process #2:    Involves screening off dangerous pollutants like formaldehyde, benzene, sulfides, and smoke using an active carbon filter.Process #3:   Involves screening off the smallest, remaining air pollutants using an Electrostatic HEPA filter. Together, these 3 processes allow Breathe Clean breathing masks to give you fresh, clean air on demand.The second way Breathe story:
Short Summary

In the United States, approximately 20% of women and 6% or more of men, experience an attempted or completed sexual assault during their college years (www.cdc.gov/violenceprevention/pdf/campussvprev...). 

The majority of students have an inadequate understanding of how to report or where to seek care following an assault.

actNOW, is an app developed to securely file a report, find appropriate healthcare, and provide support to survivors following a sexual assault. actNOW is built upon a victim-centered model, giving survivors control.

actNOW seeks to revolutionize the social culture and aftermath of sexual assault.

Your generous contribution will be applied to: 

  • Technical Development
    • Design and build a product for public beta testing 
  • Marketing
    • Conduct outreach to universities for beta testing
    • Produce and distribute marketing materials for the advancement of actNOW

Sexual Assault Impacts Everyone

Individuals from every gender, race and social class are affected by sexual assault.  

No one is immune; everyone can do something to help.

  • Every 98 seconds, someone in the United States is sexually assaulted (https://www.rainn.org/statistics) 
  • 321,500 Americans 12 and older were sexually assaulted or raped in the past year (DOJ, OJP, BJS, 2010-2014) 
  • Sexual assault remains the most under-reported crime in the US (Ullman & Bhat, 2016)


Please, share this page!  

Together, we can improve the health and well-being of thousands of people across the country.

story:
Lumbricus  Project

Earthquakes were responsible for an estimated 1.87 million deaths in the 20th century with an average of 2,052 fatalities per event affecting humans between 1990 and 2010. The magnitude 8.9 Japan earthquake and resulting tsunami in March 2011 was responsible for more than 28,000 deaths; in comparison, the smaller magnitude 7.0 earthquake occurring in Haiti in January 2010 resulted in an estimated 222,500 fatalities. In recent history, the Pacific Rim is the most affected by seismic activity, with 81% of the world’s largest earthquakes occurring in this region (Doocy et al. 2013)

Earthquakes result from sudden energy releases in the earth’s crust, which create seismic waves that result in ground shaking. Earthquakes are usually caused by slippage on a fault due to built up friction between tectonic plates but can also be caused by volcanic eruptions or manmade explosions. 

Millions of earthquakes occur each year, though only a small proportion is strong enough to be felt and even fewer cause damage. Earthquakes occur at focal depths of 700 km to just under the earth’s surface, and the strength of shaking diminishes with increasing distance from the earthquake’s source. 


Population growth and increasing urbanization in earthquake-prone areas suggest that earthquake impacts on human populations will increase in the coming decades. Recent large earthquakes affecting large populations in Japan, Haiti, Chile and New Zealand are evidence of this trend and also illustrate significant variations in outcomes such damage and mortality levels.

Global impact

Between 1960 and 2006, the ten most lethal earthquakes caused 80% of the 1 million earthquake deaths and occurred in low- and middle-income countries. The main cause of death was building collapse; unreinforced masonry buildings were associated with higher death tolls. Efforts to control and reduce earthquake mortality have made progress in wealthier earthquake prone countries but little or no progress in low- and middle-income countries. Recent experience of a strong earthquake and availability of resources for mitigation were the two strongest determinants of action for risk mitigation. Growing urbanization and populations in developing countries have increased the risk of human impacts (Spence, 2007).

According to Chan et al. (2010) China has had the greatest human impact from earthquakes of any country in the past century.

The aforementioned data suggest the importance of being able to anticipate these phenomena.

This is the main reason why it was thought the project Lumbricus.  Which is .... save as many human lives through the anticipation of the occurrence of an earthquake.

How can we achieve

Preparedness for earthquake at individual, community and organizational levels could be more effective tools in mitigating (the growing incidence) of disaster risk and ameliorating their impacts. That is, to play more significant roles in disaster risk reduction. Preparedness efforts focus on changing animals behaviors in ways that reduce people’s risk and increase their ability to cope with hazard consequences.

According to Hill (2009) animals use substrate-borne vibrations to signal in the same contexts that they use vision, hearing, touch, taste, or smell. Study of vibrational communication across animal taxa provides more than just a more complete story. Communication through substrate-borne vibration has its own constraints and opportunities not found in other signaling modalities.

The study Mitra et al. (2009) demonstrate that the earthworms respond to the seismic vibrations generated by the worm grunting technique. Worms emerge from their burrows within a few minutes following the onset of vibrations, and the number of worms surfacing is positively correlated with the signal strength.


Previous studies were the basis for assessing the idea that through earthworms could build a device for early detection of earthquakes.

In a first phase, the state of the art on the subject is made. They were permitted a manuscript is being reviewed by an international journal. In a second phase, it is expected to gather the necessary funds for the construction of a device.

Scope of Lumbricus Project

The project will have a global impact. After the construction of the device test trials were held in major seismic zones of the planet.


What it is needed for crowdfunding?

The tests allow the necessary adjustments to the device (prototype), and then build the final version. This will be distributed for free in the major seismic zones of developing countries (Chile, Peru and some Asian countries).

For this, we need materials, international logistics because their delivery is free of charge.

Prototype Design

Materials:

1.Rectangular glass or plastic container

2.Cylindrical metal bar

3.Substrate (Earth)

4.Earthworms (specific territory where the tests would be conducted)




Prototype 

It is a device built based on the scientific knowledge we have of earthworms and the theory of resonance. These aspects are able to anticipate the occurrence of earthquakes, so can save lives. 

The prototype will be tested in major seismic zones in the world (Chile, Peru and China) and continuously adjusted as trials conducted in areas of high risk of earthquakes.

It is expected by the end of 2016 and have a proven prototype delivered the most vulnerable populations of these countries. The prototypes will be distributed free.  


We know of the earthworm

Taxonomic name: Lumbricus terrestris  L.

Common names: dilly worm (English), green crawler (English), large crawler (English), night crawler (English), nitro crawler (English)

Organism type: annelid

Lumbricus terrestris is a common earthworm, or nightcrawler, which is native to Europe and has recently received attention for its invasion of North America. It has invaded areas of Canada, the northern United States and parts of northeastern Europe. Its invasion fronts aided by translocations via bait trade, agriculture, horticulture, and unintentional transport have introduced this species throughout Canada and northern hardwood forests of the United States. L. terrestris alters ecosystems by rapidly consuming leaf litter, thereby altering nutrient cycling and availability, affects seedling establishment and plant communities through its interaction with seeds. It may also displace native earthworm species

        Description

    Lumbricus terrestris is a relatively large, anecic earthworm. It is pinkish to reddish-brown in colour and typically reaches 10-25 cm in length.

    Occurs in:

    agricultural areas, natural forests, planted forests, range/grasslands, riparian zones, ruderal/disturbed, scrub/shrublands, urban areas, wetlands

    Habitat description

    Lumbricus terrestris can inhabit all soil types except coarse sands, bare rock and acidic peat (Sphagnum). It has been found to be constrained by the -15 °C isotherm. It tolerate soils with pH values as low as 3.5–3.7 and as high as about 8.L. terrestrisis not frost-tolerant indicating that it hibernates in deep soil layers during the winter (Addison, 2009; Tiunov et al., 2006; Wironen & Moore, 2006). Although often present in agricultural fields, it fares poorly due to herbicides, mechanical damage and lack of leaf litter (L. Frelich, pers. comm.).

    General impacts

    In many ecosystems and in agricultural systems earthworms are highly beneficial to soil processes (Hendrix & Bohlen, 2002). However in forest ecosystems with few or no native earthworms, introduced species can have negative effects. Earthworms are keystone detritivores that can act as “ecosystem engineers” and have the potential to change fundamental soil properties, with cascading effects on ecosystem functioning and biodiversity (Frelich et al., 2006; Eisenhaueret al., 2007; Addison, 2009)

    Exotic earthworms are a particular problem in previously earthworm-free temperate and boreal forests of North America dominated by Acer, Quercus, Betula, Pinus and Populus (Frelich et al., 2006).

    Earthworms are often classified based on their activity and feeding type, which affects their impacts on the soil (Bouché, 1977 in Addison, 2009). Dendrobaena octaedra and Dendrodrilus rubidus are epigeic species, which inhabit and feed at the soil surface. Epigeics physically disrupt the organic layer of the soil by consuming and mixing the F and H layers, producing a homogenous and granular form of organic forest floor (Addison, 2009). Lumbricus rubellus operates in two categories, 1) epigeic which inhabit and feed at the soil surface and 2) endogeic which live and feed in the mineral horizons below the organic (LFH) layer. Thus it is considered epi-endogeic in its habits, feeding on organic matter in the forest floor, but also mixing the organic material into the upper layer of mineral soil (Addison, 2009). L. terrestris is a deep-burrowing anecic earthworm, which create permanent vertical burrows in the mineral layer. They come to the surface to feed on litter and pull it down to their burrows, depositing casts of mixed organic and mineral material on the soil surface (Addison, 2009).

    Thus earthworms in different functional groups have different impacts on the soil (Frelich et al., 2006; Hale et al., 2008). Often multiple earthworm species inhabit areas of forest, and studies suggest that impacts are greater when earthworms from more than one functional group occur together (Hale et al., 2008). Earthworm invasions typically occur in waves (e.g. Hendrix & Bohlen, 2002; Eisenhauer et al., 2007), with epigeic (e.g. D. octaedra, D. rubidus) or epi-endogeic (e.g. L. rubellus) species arriving first as they are able to utilise undisturbed forest floors. The first noticeable impacts tend to be physical disruption of the stratified humus layers on the forest floor. Endogeics generally only invade after the organic layer has been modified by epigeic or epi-endogeic species. Anecic species (e.g. L. terrestris) are usually last to arrive (James & Hendrix, 2004 in Addison, 2009).

    The purported impacts of invasive earthworms are often varied between publications, and different soil types and soil layers may be affected differently by earthworm invasion. However the main effect of earthworms is to consume litter, and incorporate it into deeper soil layers, thus causing mixing of the A and O soil horizons. This causes extreme reduction of the litter layer and changes in nutrient concentrations and cycling in the soil. Other soil characteristics such as pH, porosity and decomposition rates may also be affected. Physical disruption of plant roots and mycorrhizal associations is also a common impact. These changes to fundamental soil properties have cascading effects on plant communities, microorganisms, micro and mesofauna, birds and mammals (Hale et al., 2008; Addison, 2009).

    For a detailed account of the impacts of invasive earthworms please read Earthworms Impacts Information.

    Uses

    Lumbricus terrestris is an extremely common bait species, and was found to be the most common species sold in bait stores in a survey conducted in the Upper Midwest United States whereL. terrestris is invasive (Kelleret al, 2007)

    L. terrestrisis an anecic earthworm that removes litter from the soil surface, pulling it down into the mineral layer, and deposit casts of mixed organic and mineral material on the soil surface. It is important in nutrient cycling and soil aeration in agriculture (Addison, 2009).

    Geographical range

    Native range:Lumbircus terrestris is native to Europe where it is one of the most common earthworms and has an expansive native range. However, its specific native and non-native range remains largely uncertain.

    Known introduced range: L. terrestris has invaded new locations of Europe such as Romaina, spread through large expanses of the Russian Federation, and invaded areas of Canada and northern United States that were previously glaciated and contained no native earthworms.

    Introduction pathways to new locations

    Agriculture: Can be present in potted or ball and burlap nursery stock, and sod.

    Other: Lumbricus terrestris is an extremely commonly used fish bait. Its use and abandonment as such constitutes a major method of its dispersal (Cameron et al, 2007).

    Other:Lumbricus terrestris may be dispersed by aquatic invertebrates, waterbirds, or vertebrate predators (Cameron et al, 2007).

    Road vehicles (long distance):Industrial or recreational activities may transport of soil and plant materials containing cocoons or  Lumbricus terrestris (Cameron et al, 2007).

    Local dispersal methods

    Consumption/excretion:

    Water currents:

    Management information

    There are currently no effective methods to eradicate established earthworm populations without unacceptable non-target effects. Thus the main technique for managing invasions is prevention of introductions, via various pathways (Cameronet al., 2007; Kelleret al., 2007).

    Preventative measures: One of the major pathways for earthworm introductions is believed to from release by anglers discarding unwanted live bait. Keller et al. (2007) suggest two alternatives to reduce the likelihood of further establishments while preserving the economically important live trade of earthworms. These are: 1) Replace the species currently sold with earthworm species that are unlikely to establish populations, e.g.Eudrilus eugeniae which has an extremely low invasion risk in the U.S. Midwest, and 2) Strengthen efforts to educate anglers to dispose of live earthworms responsibly, i.e. in the trash where landfill conditions are likely to kill them (Keller et al., 2007) or to prohibit the abandonment of live bait (Cameron et al., 2007).

    Management and regulatory strategies should also take into account the fact that some earthworm species, such as Lumbricus rubellus have larger impacts than others. This species is less widely distributed than other exotic species. Thus preventing its introduction to new areas is important, even if those areas are already infested with other species (Hale et al., 2006). Similarly, some forests will be more susceptible to invasion than others. Litter calcium content is likely to be an important predictor of litter decomposition rates by exotic earthworms (Holdsworth, 2008).

    Callaham et al. (2006) suggest various policy measures that could be adapted to prevent the spread of exotic earthworms. The authors suggest restrictions on transportation of soils from infested areas to non-infested areas, unless a special permit certifying that the material is free from earthworm propagules has been granted. Formalized earthworm introduction decision making tools are also recommended as an alternative to the ad hocdecisions made by regulating agencies at present. This decision-making process allows for the quarantine of materials containing propagules of earthworms that have not been identified or widely introduced previously. These quarantines would provide time to determine the ecological risk posed by the introduction of a given earthworm species into particular systems. Suggested types of information needed to determine ecological risk include mode of reproduction, number of embryos per cocoon, ecological “strategy”, and temperature, pH and moisture requirements (Callaham et al., 2006).

    Cultural measures: Successful establishment of earthworm populations is influenced by management of the site. For example, synergistic effects of the invasive weed buckthorn and exotic earthworms could be minimized by early control measures to limit the weed (Heneghan et al, 2006).

    Chemical control: Where non-native earthworms are not well established or are found in discrete populations, the use of chemical treatments to eradicate undesirable worms may be successful. Chemical control have been used in the management of golf courses. While these treatments are highly effective, the non-target effects of chemicals should be examined before large-scale utilization (Callaham et al., 2006)

Source: http://lanwebs.lander.edu/faculty/rsfox/invertebrates/lumbricus.html 

    Nutrition

    Lumbricus terrestrisis a keystone detritovore that consumes leaf litter on the soil floor.L. terrestrisleaves its burrow to rapidly consume leaf litter. Preference is related to high Ca and possibly N concentrations. Thus basswood, ash and aspen are most preferred, followed by sugar maple and maple species. Oak is less palatable due to its low Ca concentration, but will be consumed if no other leaves with higher Ca are present (Frelichet al, 2006; Suarez et al, 2006; Belote & Jones, 2009).

    Reproduction

    Lumbricus terrestrisis a reciprocally mating simultaneous hermaphrodite, which reproduces sexually with individuals mutually exchanging sperm.L. terrestrisleaves its burrow to copulate on the soil surface. Sperm is stored, and mated individuals produce cocoons for up to 12 months after the mating. A study on the hatchability of cocoons found a range of 76 to 62% hatched over the 5 months following mating, which decreased to about 11% in the sixth month, and cocoons after that failed to hatch. Median total production of viable cocoons was 5 per individual, with a range of 0-21. Sperm may be stored for as long as 8 months (Butt & Nuutinen, 1998).

Source: http://lanwebs.lander.edu/faculty/rsfox/invertebrates/lumbricus.html

story_txt:
Lumbricus  ProjectEarthquakes were responsible for an estimated 1.87 million deaths in the 20th century with an average of 2,052 fatalities per event affecting humans between 1990 and 2010. The magnitude 8.9 Japan earthquake and resulting tsunami in March 2011 was responsible for more than 28,000 deaths; in comparison, the smaller magnitude 7.0 earthquake occurring in Haiti in January 2010 resulted in an estimated 222,500 fatalities. In recent history, the Pacific Rim is the most affected by seismic activity, with 81% of the world’s largest earthquakes occurring in this region (Doocy et al. 2013)Earthquakes result from sudden energy releases in the earth’s crust, which create seismic waves that result in ground shaking. Earthquakes are usually caused by slippage on a fault due to built up friction between tectonic plates but can also be caused by volcanic eruptions or manmade explosions. Millions of earthquakes occur each year, though only a small proportion is strong enough to be felt and even fewer cause damage. Earthquakes occur at focal depths of 700 km to just under the earth’s surface, and the strength of shaking diminishes with increasing distance from the earthquake’s source. Population growth and increasing urbanization in earthquake-prone areas suggest that earthquake impacts on human populations will increase in the coming decades. Recent large earthquakes affecting large populations in Japan, Haiti, Chile and New Zealand are evidence of this trend and also illustrate significant variations in outcomes such damage and mortality levels.Global impactBetween 1960 and 2006, the ten most lethal earthquakes caused 80% of the 1 million earthquake deaths and occurred in low- and middle-income countries. The main cause of death was building collapse; unreinforced masonry buildings were associated with higher death tolls. Efforts to control and reduce earthquake mortality have made progress in wealthier earthquake prone countries but little or no progress in low- and middle-income countries. Recent experience of a strong earthquake and availability of resources for mitigation were the two strongest determinants of action for risk mitigation. Growing urbanization and populations in developing countries have increased the risk of human impacts (Spence, 2007).According to Chan et al. (2010) China has had the greatest human impact from earthquakes of any country in the past century.The aforementioned data suggest the importance of being able to anticipate these phenomena.This is the main reason why it was thought the project Lumbricus.  Which is .... save as many human lives through the anticipation of the occurrence of an earthquake.How can we achievePreparedness for earthquake at individual, community and organizational levels could be more effective tools in mitigating (the growing incidence) of disaster risk and ameliorating their impacts. That is, to play more significant roles in disaster risk reduction. Preparedness efforts focus on changing animals behaviors in ways that reduce people’s risk and increase their ability to cope with hazard consequences.According to Hill (2009) animals use substrate-borne vibrations to signal in the same contexts that they use vision, hearing, touch, taste, or smell. Study of vibrational communication across animal taxa provides more than just a more complete story. Communication through substrate-borne vibration has its own constraints and opportunities not found in other signaling modalities.The study Mitra et al. (2009) demonstrate that the earthworms respond to the seismic vibrations generated by the worm grunting technique. Worms emerge from their burrows within a few minutes following the onset of vibrations, and the number of worms surfacing is positively correlated with the signal strength.Previous studies were the basis for assessing the idea that through earthworms could build a device for early detection of earthquakes.In a first phase, the state of the art on the subject is made. They were permitted a manuscript is being reviewed by an international journal. In a second phase, it is expected to gather the necessary funds for the construction of a device.Scope of Lumbricus ProjectThe project will have a global impact. After the construction of the device test trials were held in major seismic zones of the planet.What it is needed for crowdfunding?The tests allow the necessary adjustments to the device (prototype), and then build the final version. This will be distributed for free in the major seismic zones of developing countries (Chile, Peru and some Asian countries).For this, we need materials, international logistics because their delivery is free of charge.Prototype DesignMaterials:1.Rectangular glass or plastic container2.Cylindrical metal bar3.Substrate (Earth)4.Earthworms (specific territory where the tests would be conducted)Prototype It is a device built based on the scientific knowledge we have of earthworms and the theory of resonance. These aspects are able to anticipate the occurrence of earthquakes, so can save lives. The prototype will be tested in major seismic zones in the world (Chile, Peru and China) and continuously adjusted as trials conducted in areas of high risk of earthquakes.It is expected by the end of 2016 and have a proven prototype delivered the most vulnerable populations of these countries. The prototypes will be distributed free.  We know of the earthwormTaxonomic name: Lumbricus terrestris  L.Common names: dilly worm (English), green crawler (English), large crawler (English), night crawler (English), nitro crawler (English)Organism type: annelidLumbricus terrestris is a common earthworm, or nightcrawler, which is native to Europe and has recently received attention for its invasion of North America. It has invaded areas of Canada, the northern United States and parts of northeastern Europe. Its invasion fronts aided by translocations via bait trade, agriculture, horticulture, and unintentional transport have introduced this species throughout Canada and northern hardwood forests of the United States. L. terrestris alters ecosystems by rapidly consuming leaf litter, thereby altering nutrient cycling and availability, affects seedling establishment and plant communities through its interaction with seeds. It may also displace native earthworm species        DescriptionLumbricus terrestris is a relatively large, anecic earthworm. It is pinkish to reddish-brown in colour and typically reaches 10-25 cm in length.
Occurs in:
agricultural areas, natural forests, planted forests, range/grasslands, riparian zones, ruderal/disturbed, scrub/shrublands, urban areas, wetlands

Habitat description
Lumbricus terrestris can inhabit all soil types except coarse sands, bare rock and acidic peat (Sphagnum). It has been found to be constrained by the -15 °C isotherm. It tolerate soils with pH values as low as 3.5–3.7 and as high as about 8.L. terrestrisis not frost-tolerant indicating that it hibernates in deep soil layers during the winter (Addison, 2009; Tiunov et al., 2006; Wironen & Moore, 2006). Although often present in agricultural fields, it fares poorly due to herbicides, mechanical damage and lack of leaf litter (L. Frelich, pers. comm.).

General impacts
In many ecosystems and in agricultural systems earthworms are highly beneficial to soil processes (Hendrix & Bohlen, 2002). However in forest ecosystems with few or no native earthworms, introduced species can have negative effects. Earthworms are keystone detritivores that can act as “ecosystem engineers” and have the potential to change fundamental soil properties, with cascading effects on ecosystem functioning and biodiversity (Frelich et al., 2006; Eisenhaueret al., 2007; Addison, 2009)
Exotic earthworms are a particular problem in previously earthworm-free temperate and boreal forests of North America dominated by Acer, Quercus, Betula, Pinus and Populus (Frelich et al., 2006).
Earthworms are often classified based on their activity and feeding type, which affects their impacts on the soil (Bouché, 1977 in Addison, 2009). Dendrobaena octaedra and Dendrodrilus rubidus are epigeic species, which inhabit and feed at the soil surface. Epigeics physically disrupt the organic layer of the soil by consuming and mixing the F and H layers, producing a homogenous and granular form of organic forest floor (Addison, 2009). Lumbricus rubellus operates in two categories, 1) epigeic which inhabit and feed at the soil surface and 2) endogeic which live and feed in the mineral horizons below the organic (LFH) layer. Thus it is considered epi-endogeic in its habits, feeding on organic matter in the forest floor, but also mixing the organic material into the upper layer of mineral soil (Addison, 2009). L. terrestris is a deep-burrowing anecic earthworm, which create permanent vertical burrows in the mineral layer. They come to the surface to feed on litter and pull it down to their burrows, depositing casts of mixed organic and mineral material on the soil surface (Addison, 2009).
Thus earthworms in different functional groups have different impacts on the soil (Frelich et al., 2006; Hale et al., 2008). Often multiple earthworm species inhabit areas of forest, and studies suggest that impacts are greater when earthworms from more than one functional group occur together (Hale et al., 2008). Earthworm invasions typically occur in waves (e.g. Hendrix & Bohlen, 2002; Eisenhauer et al., 2007), with epigeic (e.g. D. octaedra, D. rubidus) or epi-endogeic (e.g. L. rubellus) species arriving first as they are able to utilise undisturbed forest floors. The first noticeable impacts tend to be physical disruption of the stratified humus layers on the forest floor. Endogeics generally only invade after the organic layer has been modified by epigeic or epi-endogeic species. Anecic species (e.g. L. terrestris) are usually last to arrive (James & Hendrix, 2004 in Addison, 2009).
The purported impacts of invasive earthworms are often varied between publications, and different soil types and soil layers may be affected differently by earthworm invasion. However the main effect of earthworms is to consume litter, and incorporate it into deeper soil layers, thus causing mixing of the A and O soil horizons. This causes extreme reduction of the litter layer and changes in nutrient concentrations and cycling in the soil. Other soil characteristics such as pH, porosity and decomposition rates may also be affected. Physical disruption of plant roots and mycorrhizal associations is also a common impact. These changes to fundamental soil properties have cascading effects on plant communities, microorganisms, micro and mesofauna, birds and mammals (Hale et al., 2008; Addison, 2009).
For a detailed account of the impacts of invasive earthworms please read Earthworms Impacts Information.

Uses
Lumbricus terrestris is an extremely common bait species, and was found to be the most common species sold in bait stores in a survey conducted in the Upper Midwest United States whereL. terrestris is invasive (Kelleret al, 2007)
L. terrestrisis an anecic earthworm that removes litter from the soil surface, pulling it down into the mineral layer, and deposit casts of mixed organic and mineral material on the soil surface. It is important in nutrient cycling and soil aeration in agriculture (Addison, 2009).

Geographical range
Native range:Lumbircus terrestris is native to Europe where it is one of the most common earthworms and has an expansive native range. However, its specific native and non-native range remains largely uncertain.
Known introduced range: L. terrestris has invaded new locations of Europe such as Romaina, spread through large expanses of the Russian Federation, and invaded areas of Canada and northern United States that were previously glaciated and contained no native earthworms.

Introduction pathways to new locations
Agriculture: Can be present in potted or ball and burlap nursery stock, and sod.
Other: Lumbricus terrestris is an extremely commonly used fish bait. Its use and abandonment as such constitutes a major method of its dispersal (Cameron et al, 2007).
Other:Lumbricus terrestris may be dispersed by aquatic invertebrates, waterbirds, or vertebrate predators (Cameron et al, 2007).
Road vehicles (long distance):Industrial or recreational activities may transport of soil and plant materials containing cocoons or  Lumbricus terrestris (Cameron et al, 2007).
Local dispersal methods
Consumption/excretion:
Water currents:

Management information
There are currently no effective methods to eradicate established earthworm populations without unacceptable non-target effects. Thus the main technique for managing invasions is prevention of introductions, via various pathways (Cameronet al., 2007; Kelleret al., 2007).
Preventative measures: One of the major pathways for earthworm introductions is believed to from release by anglers discarding unwanted live bait. Keller et al. (2007) suggest two alternatives to reduce the likelihood of further establishments while preserving the economically important live trade of earthworms. These are: 1) Replace the species currently sold with earthworm species that are unlikely to establish populations, e.g.Eudrilus eugeniae which has an extremely low invasion risk in the U.S. Midwest, and 2) Strengthen efforts to educate anglers to dispose of live earthworms responsibly, i.e. in the trash where landfill conditions are likely to kill them (Keller et al., 2007) or to prohibit the abandonment of live bait (Cameron et al., 2007).
Management and regulatory strategies should also take into account the fact that some earthworm species, such as Lumbricus rubellus have larger impacts than others. This species is less widely distributed than other exotic species. Thus preventing its introduction to new areas is important, even if those areas are already infested with other species (Hale et al., 2006). Similarly, some forests will be more susceptible to invasion than others. Litter calcium content is likely to be an important predictor of litter decomposition rates by exotic earthworms (Holdsworth, 2008).
Callaham et al. (2006) suggest various policy measures that could be adapted to prevent the spread of exotic earthworms. The authors suggest restrictions on transportation of soils from infested areas to non-infested areas, unless a special permit certifying that the material is free from earthworm propagules has been granted. Formalized earthworm introduction decision making tools are also recommended as an alternative to the ad hocdecisions made by regulating agencies at present. This decision-making process allows for the quarantine of materials containing propagules of earthworms that have not been identified or widely introduced previously. These quarantines would provide time to determine the ecological risk posed by the introduction of a given earthworm species into particular systems. Suggested types of information needed to determine ecological risk include mode of reproduction, number of embryos per cocoon, ecological “strategy”, and temperature, pH and moisture requirements (Callaham et al., 2006).
Cultural measures: Successful establishment of earthworm populations is influenced by management of the site. For example, synergistic effects of the invasive weed buckthorn and exotic earthworms could be minimized by early control measures to limit the weed (Heneghan et al, 2006).
Chemical control: Where non-native earthworms are not well established or are found in discrete populations, the use of chemical treatments to eradicate undesirable worms may be successful. Chemical control have been used in the management of golf courses. While these treatments are highly effective, the non-target effects of chemicals should be examined before large-scale utilization (Callaham et al., 2006)

story:
Stem Cell byproduct from JAPAN!
  • This CAMPAIGN is here to promote our BYPRODUCT - KINTARO CELLS ENRICHED MEDIUM - for both COSMETIC BEAUTY
  • If this campaign succeeds we will be able to produce all our products in larger quantity; faster, and in a new beautiful and more durable container.
  • (If we don't reach our goal you will still get the product in it's original prototype model, although shipping times may be delayed)
 

  • Because this product hasn’t hit the market yet, we would like to present you this opportunity to get EARLY PRODUCT DISCOUNTS (PERKS) and other services and features, including:

When are the PRODUCT LAUNCH campaign DATES?

Our company will run this campaign for 5 Weeks Only until June 1st - Don't miss this opportunity!

 

Why CROWD FUNDING?

The goal of this campaign is to raise money to help us launch our new cosmetic product KC Enriched Medium. Although we have a working prototype of our product, we require more funds to produce a cosmetic product that is as aesthetically appealing as it has been proven effective. Better appeal means more sales of our bi-product, which drives more funding for continued research with KINTARO CELLS!

 

Other Ways You Can Help!

We understand it isn't always financially easy to donate. The "Golden Boy" Kintaro lived on the mountains with his mother for many years before he became a prosperous Samuari. If your balance is lost in the mountains too, you can still find ways to help - just like Kintaro did:

  • Tell your friends, family, and co-workers about this wonderful product! Kintaro Cells Enriched Medium makes an excellent gift for a parent or partner!
  • Blog about us online! Our team would love to hear about people like you spreading the word!
  • Share our link on Facebook!
  • Ask us about being a sales agent for KINTARO CELLS!
  • Introduce us to more connections! Know any doctors/clinics/research centers that use BM-MSC? We'd love to get to know them! The only way to better the world is to work together!

Thanks for your attention! Or - as we say in Japan - DOMO ARIGATO!!

Stem Cell byproduct from JAPAN!
This CAMPAIGN is here to promote our BYPRODUCT - KINTARO CELLS ENRICHED MEDIUM - for both COSMETIC BEAUTY
